hints.content:
A common type of double replacement reaction occurs when two dissolved salts switch cations to produce a solid *precipitate*:

$\ce{\redD{\ce{A}}B}(aq) + \ce{\blueD{\ce{C}}D}(aq) \rightarrow \ce{\blueD{\ce{C}}B}(aq) + \ce{\redD{\ce{A}}D}\redD{(s)}$

To answer this question, we will first identify the potential products. Then we can use our solubility rules to determine if one of them is insoluble. If both potential products are soluble, the reaction will not occur.

Let’s start by identifying the potential products. 

$\ce{KCl}(aq) + \ce{MgSO4}(aq)  \rightarrow {?}$

Swapping the cations results in two new combinations: $\ce{K+}$ with $\ce{SO4^2-},$ and $\ce{Mg^2+}$ with  $\ce{Cl-}.$

(We don’t need to worry about the correct formulas yet; let’s first determine if the reaction will even happen!)

To determine if a salt is soluble or insoluble, solubility rules are usually memorized or looked up. You can find a solubility chart in this article. 

When $\ce{K+}$ combines with $\ce{SO4^2-},$ we see the result is soluble. And when $\ce{Mg^2+}$ combines with $\ce{Cl-},$  the result is *also* soluble. 

So, there is no double replacement reaction. All four ions remain dissolved in solution and no solid precipitate will form.
So when a solution of potassium chloride is added to a solution of magnesium sulfate, there will be no reaction.
